evidence_refs: 3.1: Hyperscaler partner credit compression (20-25% historical to 10-15% current, causing 30-65% gross margin compression)
3.1: VMware/Broadcom monopoly pricing (200-300% increase = $100-210M annual value extraction)
3.1: Managed services commoditization (MSP margins compressed from 15-25% to 5-15% over decade)
3.1: Scale economics impossibility vs fragmentation ($4-5B required, stuck at $1.38B with 25.9% SG&A)
3.5: Hyperscaler marketplace dependency ratchet (15-30% penetration growing to 50-70%, mandatory 3-7% fees)
3.5: Compliance cost inflation (FedRAMP, UK Sovereign $5-10M annually = 4-8% of Government revenue)
3.6: AI-driven automation eliminating 70-80% of MSP value proposition
3.6: Cloud-native architecture adoption destroying Private Cloud demand ($1,055M to $100-200M over 10 years)
criterion_1_external_forces_3_plus.notes: PASS - At least 8 distinct external pressure forces identified and evidenced with quantification. Far exceeds minimum threshold of 3. Forces span supplier power (hyperscalers, VMware), market evolution (commoditization, AI), structural constraints (scale, fragmentation), and technology shifts (cloud-native).

evidence_refs: 3.1: Hyperscalers control 89.6% value capture vs Rackspace 10.4%, <0.5% revenue materiality creates zero negotiating leverage
3.1: VMware/Broadcom unilateral 200-300% price increase, Rackspace must absorb with zero negotiating power
3.2: Hyperscalers compete while controlling infrastructure layer (vertical integration allowing subsidization)
3.2: Low-cost MSPs operate with 50-70% labor cost advantage, Rackspace structurally locked to high-cost model
3.5: Platform vendors (hyperscalers, VMware, marketplaces) extract rent unilaterally without competitive pressure
criterion_2_power_asymmetries_2_plus.notes: PASS - At least 5 major power asymmetries documented, all unfavorable to Rackspace, all evidenced with quantification. Asymmetries exist across supplier relationships, competitive positioning, and platform dependencies.

evidence_refs: 3.1: Hyperscaler partner credit compression damages margins without customer switching (input cost absorbed by Rackspace, customers experience zero change)
3.5: Partner credits declined 10 percentage points causing 30-65% gross margin compression, zero customer involvement
3.1: VMware 200-300% price increase extracted $100-210M value without competing for customers directly
3.2: Integrated vendor bundling (IBM/Oracle bundle managed services at zero margin) resets customer price expectations without head-to-head
3.5: Hyperscaler marketplace fees (3-7%) extract value as mandatory toll, competitive damage without customer displacement
criterion_3_non_head_to_head_threat.notes: PASS - Multiple mechanisms documented where competitive/supplier threats damage economics without head-to-head customer competition. Includes margin compression via platform control, rent extraction, bundling effects, and expectation resets.

evidence_refs: 3.4: 'Fanatical Support creates pricing power' INVALIDATED - Email 706% price increase failed catastrophically (45% revenue loss), 21% bookings decline despite brand emphasis

3.3: 'High renewal rates indicate loyalty' INVALIDATED - Private Cloud 85-95% retention yet -13% revenue decline proves retained customers shrinking spend, renewals measure constraint not satisfaction
3.3: 'Retention is earned through service quality' INVALIDATED - Stage 2.4 explicitly states retention is 'STRUCTURAL not earned', depends on switching costs not service quality
3.4: 'Switching costs enable price increases' INVALIDATED - high switching costs create retention but NOT pricing power, customers overcome barriers when economics justify
3.2: 'Low competitive intensity in compliance segments' INVALIDATED - FedRAMP has ~100 authorized providers, Government faces quality competition not quantity scarcity
criterion_4_false_belief_invalidated.notes: PASS - At least 5 major false beliefs about customer loyalty, pricing power, service differentiation, and competitive protection systematically invalidated with evidence. Email segment provides definitive disproof of pricing power beliefs.

evidence_refs: 3.6: Economic recession causes PERMANENT customer migration (customers who switch during stress don't return, switching costs work both directions), adverse selection degrades portfolio quality forever
3.6: AI-driven automation creates IRREVERSIBLE MSP business model obsolescence (democratized expertise never reverses, customers who learn AI-enabled self-management never return to outsourcing)
3.6: Cloud-native architecture adoption causes PERMANENT Private Cloud demand destruction ($1,055M contracts to $100-200M over 10 years, one-way architectural evolution)
3.6: Data sovereignty mandates create PERMANENT market fragmentation (regulations politically irreversible, scale economics destroyed forever across jurisdictions)
3.6: US-China technology decoupling causes PERMANENT/GENERATIONAL addressable market fragmentation (20-30+ year strategic competition timeframe)
criterion_5_irreversible_shock.notes: PASS - At least 5 distinct external shocks documented as causing irreversible damage or permanent power transfer. Shocks span macro (recession), technological (AI, cloud-native), regulatory (sovereignty), and geopolitical (decoupling). Each includes explicit analysis of why recovery is structurally impossible.
